data.prompt: A caravan of N camels must transport as many bananas as possible from oasis A to oasis B, M miles away. Each camel can carry at most C bananas and eats one banana per mile traveled (carried or not). Bananas can be dropped and picked up en route. For N=3, C=3000, M=1000, what is the maximum bananas deliverable to B?
hints: Stage the journey: initially all 3 shuttle to move stock forward.
Burn rate changes with active camels; compute breakpoint distances.
Classic answer sequence yields 533 bananas delivered.

data.prompt: You face two guards: one always tells the truth, one always lies. One bridge leads to freedom, the other to doom. You may ask a single question to one guard to guarantee choosing the freedom bridge. Provide a question that works regardless of whom you ask.
answers: if i asked the other guard which bridge leads to freedom, what would he say? then take the other
hints: Force both types to point at the same (wrong) bridge.
Ask about what the other would say; invert the answer.
Take the opposite of the indicated bridge.

data.prompt: Two integers x and y satisfy 2 < x < y and x + y ≤ 100. S (told the sum) says: 'I don't know the numbers, but I knew P (told the product) couldn't know.' P says: 'Now I know the numbers.' S says: 'Now I know them too.' What are x and y? Enter them as two numbers (order doesn't matter).
hints: S's first statement eliminates sums that can be expressed as a sum of two primes in only one way (Goldbach-like reasoning for even sums).
P then refines by products that factor uniquely under the remaining sums.
The unique resolution is {4,13}.

data.prompt: A 10×10×10 cube is painted on the outside, then cut into 1×1×1 cubes. How many small cubes have exactly two faces painted?
hints: Count edge cubes excluding corners.
Each of the 12 edges contributes (n−2) such cubes.
Compute 12×(10−2).

data.prompt: 100 lockers start closed. On pass k (1..100), you toggle every k-th locker. After 100 passes, how many lockers are open?
hints: A locker ends open iff it is toggled an odd number of times.
That happens exactly for perfect squares.
Count squares ≤ 100.

data.prompt: From an 8×8 chessboard, remove two opposite corner squares. Can the remaining 62 squares be tiled by 31 dominoes (each covering two adjacent squares)?
hints: Color parity argument.
Domino covers one black and one white square.
The modified board has unequal counts of colors.

data.prompt: You have 2 identical eggs and a 100-floor building. Find the minimal worst-case number of drops to determine the highest floor from which an egg can be dropped without breaking.
hints: Choose floors to minimize the maximum remaining checks after a break.
Use a decreasing-step strategy k,(k−1),(k−2),... so k(k+1)/2 ≥ 100.
Smallest k with k(k+1)/2 ≥ 100 is 14.

data.prompt: Call a number untouchable if it is not the sum of proper divisors of any positive integer. Prove or disprove: 5 is untouchable, and find the smallest even untouchable number. Enter your numeric answer(s) as a set (space-separated, any order).
hints: Use parity and bounds on σ(n)−n for odd/even n.
Check small cases and exploit that sums for odd n are odd.
The smallest even untouchable is 2.

puzzles.title: Two Knights, One Knave, Three Statements

data.prompt: On an island, Knights always tell the truth and Knaves always lie. You meet A, B, and C. A says: 'B is a Knave.' B says: 'A and C are of the same type.' C says: 'I am a Knight.' Determine the types of A, B, and C.
answers: a knight, b knave, c knave
hints: Assume C is Knight and derive contradiction.
Use B's claim to couple A and C; combine with A's accusation.
Only A=Knight, B=Knave, C=Knave satisfies all constraints.

data.prompt: Countably many prisoners stand in a line, each wearing a red or blue hat, seeing all hats in front but not their own or behind. Simultaneously they must say 'red' or 'blue'. Design a strategy to ensure only finitely many are wrong almost surely, and state the minimal bound achievable. Answer with the minimal bound as a number.
hints: Use equivalence classes modulo a tail-equivalence relation.
The Axiom of Choice can select a representative sequence (non-constructive).
All but finitely many prisoners can be correct; in some formulations you can force all but 0 errors on almost all sample paths (measure-theoretic subtlety).

data.prompt: Given a finite set of points in the plane, not all collinear, prove there exists a line containing exactly two of the points. For this set: 7 points in general position (no three collinear), provide the minimum number of ordinary lines. Enter the number.
hints: Sylvester–Gallai theorem.
In general position with n points, at least n ordinary lines.
For 7 points, minimum is 7.

data.prompt: How many domino tilings does the order-n Aztec diamond have? Provide the closed form in terms of n as a sequence expression (e.g., '2^(n(n+1)/2)').
hints: Use the shuffling algorithm or induction via condensation.
The exponent is quadratic in n.
Check small n to spot the pattern.

data.prompt: Express 5/121 as a sum of distinct unit fractions with the smallest number of terms. Enter denominators as a tuple 'a b c ...'.
hints: Greedy algorithm suggests 1/25 first.
Reduce the remainder and continue.
Simplify to distinct unit fractions.

data.prompt: Outside a closed room are three light switches; inside the room are three bulbs. Each switch controls one bulb. You may manipulate the switches as you like but may enter the room only once. How can you determine which switch controls which bulb?
answers: turn one on, one on then off, one off; heat reveals the second
hints: Exploit both on/off state and thermal state.
Leave one switch on, one on briefly then off, one off.
Identify hot, warm, and cold bulbs to map switches.

data.prompt: 41 people stand in a circle numbered 1..41. Starting at 1, every 3rd person is eliminated (wrapping around). Which position survives?
hints: This is a Josephus problem J(n, k).
Use recurrence J(n,k) = (J(n-1,k) + k) mod n with J(1,k)=0, then add 1.
Alternatively, compute in base-2 decomposition for k=2; here k=3 so use recurrence or code mentally.

data.prompt: You have a 3-liter and a 3-liter jug and an unlimited water source. Can you measure exactly 1 liter? If not, adjust the capacities to the classic pair and give a minimal sequence to measure 1 liter.
hints: With two equal jugs (3,3) you cannot get 1 liter; gcd(3,3)=3.
Use 3 and 5 liter jugs; gcd(3,5)=1 allows any integer measure.
Fill 3→pour to 5 (2 left in 5), empty 5, pour 1 to 5, fill 3 and top 5 to leave 1 in 3.

data.prompt:
Find the unique integer X with 100 ≤ X ≤ 999 such that exactly one of the following statements is true (the other two are false).
(1) X is divisible by the sum of its digits.
(2) Reversing the decimal digits of X increases it by 198.
(3) X is a perfect square.
hints: Let X = 100a + 10b + c. Then reverse(X) − X = 99(c − a).
If (2) holds, 198 = 99 × 2, so c − a = 2 with c > a.
Try X with hundreds and ones digits that differ by 2, then test (1) and (3).
One solution is X = 254. Then reverse is 452 (difference 198), X is not divisible by 2+5+4=11, and it is not a square.

hints: Solve the 1-blue-eyed base case, then 2, and generalize.

Induction on k shows departure on the k-th night.

data.prompt: Four people need to cross a bridge at night with one torch. They take 1, 2, 7, and 10 minutes respectively. Only two can cross at a time and the group must walk at the slower person's pace; the torch must be carried. What is the minimum total time to get everyone across?
hints: Try both strategies: always send the fastest back vs pairing the two slowest together smartly.

hints: The leading letters S and M cannot be zero.

hints: Each weighing has three outcomes; consider information capacity.
Partition possibilities to keep them balanced across outcomes.
